title: Question 67

children: A 52-year-old man undergoes follow-up evaluation after initial testing for fevers up to 38.4 °C (101.2 °F) recurring over the past 8 weeks. He has no other symptoms. His weight has been stable, and he continues to work. He has never traveled outside the United States; reports no tick or insect bites or animal exposures; and does not consume raw meat, raw seafood, or unpasteurized dairy products.
On physical examination, temperature is 37.8 °C (100 °F), blood pressure is 116/74 mm Hg, pulse rate is 84/min, and respiration rate is 16/min. The examination is unremarkable.
Urinalysis is normal. HIV serology, interferon-γ release assay, rheumatoid factor, and antinuclear antibody test results are negative. Three sets of blood cultures are negative.
A chest radiograph is normal, and CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis with and without contrast is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

In patients with classic fever of unknown origin (fever >38.3 °C [100.9 °F] for >3 weeks that remains undiagnosed after careful extensive evaluation and two visits in the ambulatory setting), no further testing or treatment is indicated.
The prognosis for fever of unknown origin is good for adults who remain undiagnosed after extensive evaluation.
Clinical observation is the most appropriate management at this time (

). The patient meets the criteria for classic fever of unknown origin (FUO): fever greater than 38.3 °C (100.9 °F) for more than 3 weeks that remains undiagnosed after two visits in the ambulatory setting. A careful, detailed history is the first step in evaluating a patient with FUO. The history should be repeated at each visit because subtle clues may be revealed only with repeated questioning. A complete medical, occupational, and social history should be elicited followed by a careful comprehensive examination to guide further testing. When the initial evaluation is unrevealing, CT of the abdomen and pelvis (with and without contrast) should be obtained. When imaging results are normal, continued clinical observation is the appropriate next step. The prognosis is good for adults who remain undiagnosed after extensive evaluation (nearly half of patients remain undiagnosed), and fever often spontaneously resolves in weeks to months.
